titlePage.titlePart: An Original Drama in three acts.

performance.p: First Performed at the Royal Olympic Theatre, on Monday, October 17th, 1853.

castItem.roleDesc: (head Of The Secret Department Of Police)

set.p: Scene - Acts 1 and 3 in Paris. Act 2 near Prague.

list.item: Fouché.—1st Costume—The long black soutane of an Abbé, with black skull cap, covering the tonsure; black bands, with narrow white edging and narrow black cloak at the back; silk stockings; shoes and buckles; white wig. 2nd Costume—Blue velvet court coat, embroidered with gold, in the fashion of the Empire; white satin waistcoat and breeches; sword; silk stockings and shoes; iron-grey hair, cut straight on forehead, long at sides and back.
Desmarets.—Black suit, breeches, and buckles. In 2nd Act—Long boots; iron-grey hair, cut close in front, long behind.

De Cevennes and De Neuville.—Maroon and chocolate coats, with high collars and long lapelles, satin waistcoats, and breeches. De C., in Act 2—Leather breeches and long-topped boots. De N., in Act 2—Blue stockings, rich pantaloons, and high boots,
Berthier.—Crimson velvet court suit, white satin waistcoat, and breeches, and sword.
Madame de Fontanges.—Elegant evening dress. Act 2—White dress, broad-leafed straw hat, blue sash cloak. Act 3, as in Act 2.
Cecile.—Madras on the head, long hose mittens.

body.head: Plot and Passion

div.head: Act I.
div.stage: Scene—An apartment in the house of Madame de Fontanges. The room is spacious and handsomely furnished in the semi-classical style of the empire, with large folding doors communicating (in flat) with an adjoining room. A secret door in the wall (R.) concealed by a picture, and another side-door communicating with the staircase. Windows practicable. (L.) A writing table with writing materials. (L. C.) Caraffe of water and glasses. Fauteuils disposed about the stage. Fire-place between the windows, with bronze pendule and candelabra, and a glass over it.
Cecile at the fire-place. Jabot arranging the inkstand and a breviary on the table.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Seven o'clock, and Madame not returned! astonishing!

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: Cecile, how often must I repeat to you that servants in a good family ought never to be astonished? Madame is young, charming, a widow, and may choose her own hours.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: For her visitors—yes; but you forget this is her night for receiving her Confessor; she never would dare to keep the Abbé Lenoir waiting.

sp.speaker: Jab.
sp.p: Pooh! she must leave a few of her sins to stand over till next week—there's a running account between them. When the Abbé arrives shew him in here, and take care he is not disturbed in his pious exercises.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Hark! there's a fiacre in the court (she looks out) The Abbé! (she arranges her cap and hair at the glass. A ring is heard)

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: What! even for an Abbé!

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Why not? one must shew some respect for the church, Monsieur Jabot. Exit Cecile, C.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: Oh, woman! woman! As if that walking monument of mortification had eyes for a waiting maid!Re-enter Cecile shewing in Fouché in the dress of an Abbé. He walks with an air of pious abstraction; his hands folded, and his eyes cast down.

sp.speaker: Jab.
sp.p: (R., wheeling an arm chair forward)Madame, unfortunately, has not yet returned—but she expected your Reverence's visit.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: (L)And directed that we should show every attention to your Reverence's wishes.

sp.speaker: Fouché.
sp.p: Thank you, my children—I wish to be alone— see that no one enters this room, except your mistress, or my other penitent, M. de Cevennes, should he arrive.Jabot bows, Cecile curtsies, and exeunt, L. Fouché, rising, takes a rapid survey of the room, then closes the window curtains, places the lights on the mantelpiece, and bolts the door by which they have gone, and also the folding-doors.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Never trust an order while there's a bolt. Now for my ferret:—to all but me, M. le Bon, the respectable proprietor of the house next door—to me, Maximilian Desmarets, the most unmitigated rascal and most invaluable head of a secret department in Europe. It was a good idea of mine to establish him next door to Madame de Fontanges. We meet here unobserved. (He touches a spring in the frame of the picture, R. It moves, and discovers a secret door) Hist! Desmarets!Enter from the secret door Desmarets, with a despatch-box and papers. He takes a chair at the table, opens his box, unfolds his papers (R.), and sits looking at Fouche.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: At least, I am sure to find YOU at your post! (Desmarets chuckles and rubs his hands) These women think only of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Desmarets.
sp.p: So do I—my pleasure's here! (pointing to papers)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I pay Madame de Fontanges enough to ensure diligence, too.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Madame receives exactly double what I do. Suppose you reversed the proportions?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You would serve me no better, and she would not serve me at all; besides, she has the enormous recommendation of an unblemished character!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: She!—so much for the world's judgment of a confirmed gambler!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: That is her only vice—a secret confined to us, and her mask! It was a good thought to allow of masks at the public tables.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Do they hide many blushes?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: They save many reputations. No, my excellent Desmarets, I have not spent twenty years in guaging the price of consciences without arriving at a tolerably fair estimate of the money value of my species, from Kings downwards.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: And you think my fidelity is worth just four thousand francs a month?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: With your character I think no one would pay half as much for your treachery.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: You think so?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: If anybody should make the offer let me know, and we can enter into a fresh arrangement!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah! you know my heart is devoted to you!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I know your head is, and, as times go, that is perhaps a better security. But to work:—first, your despatches from England!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Two.—(takes papers) One from Mons. Ouvrard, announcing that he has opened a negotiation for peace in your name, with the Foreign Secretary, but that he fears your other agent, Mons. Fagan, is not to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Ordered—that M. Ouvrard keep a strict watch over M. Fagan. (Desmarets makes a note on the despatch) And the other?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: From M. Fagan, stating that your overtures for peace have been most favourably received by the English Prime Minister, but that he has reason to believe M. Ouvrard is in the pay of the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Ordered—that M. Fagan establish a close espionage on M. Ouvrard. (Desmaret's makes a note on despatch as before) I have long found the advantage of running my agents in couples. Two rogues so employed are as good as one honest man!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: And so much easier found.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: The envoy of the Emperor has not yet arrived in London?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (referring to another paper)No; he reached Amsterdam on the 3rd, but he will not sail for three weeks. I have made the necessary arrangements.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Good; by that time I shall have concluded my negociations, and the Emperor will have found himself once more anticipated by his Minister of Police. We must teach these people that they cannot do without us.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: It is a dangerous lesson sometimes with such pupils as the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Hem! he has trusted me too far, Desmarets. Those letters, from his own hand, extending over the last ten years, are my security. While I have those, I stake his credit against my portfolio.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: And those letters, thanks to my skill in iron work, are safe in their secret deposit yonder (pointing off to secret door) How lucky the Revolution made a locksmith of me when it made a Member of the National Convention of you!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Yes, we have both been able to serve the state and ourselves—go on.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (takes a pamphlet up)From our London correspondent for printed papers—another of those pamphlets signed “Timon,” which have been already found so disagreeable in high quarters.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Another? Is the Emperor never to be released from these attacks? Has this one reached France?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Thirty thousand copies have been distributed, but I am sorry to say I have not yet discovered by what channel, which is the more annoying as this one is not directed against the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Indeed! against whom, then?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Against yourself!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Ah! (starts up)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: It gives a very minute and apparently accurate account of your career.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: No matter. (uneasily)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: From the date of your Professorship at Nantes all is recorded—your strong measures in the Convention—your speeches in the Jacobin Club—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Enough, enough!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: What he calls your peculations in the Nièvre—your vote for the death of the King—your establishment of the Goddess of Reason in the Nivernais—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Pshaw! A truce to those youthful indiscretions.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Your massacre at Lyons—your—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (striking sharply on the table)Desmarets, the mind of France must not be poisoned in this way!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Unfortunately the facts are supported by regular official documents.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: They are forgeries—I destroyed all those papers when I became Minister.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: They may have been preserved, or copied.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Impossible! you alone had access to them besides myself!—Desmarets, how comes it this man is not discovered before this?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! What do you say to this. (Rises, and shows a written paper much frayed and dirtied) If we have not the man we have his handwriting.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Give it me. How did you get this?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Through one of my agents—a compositor of the London printer, who puts into type these detestable calumnies.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Your register of handwritings—quick! (Desmarets gives a small book which he takes from the box) Peltier, Fontaine, De Coigny, Talon. None of the known hands—Yet it is clearly not a feigned character. It is flowing, bold, natural!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Like that of a man who believes what he writes, and glories in writing it—The wretch! (rubs his hands)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I must have this scribbler, Desmarets, (stopping) do you hear? I must have him; the author of these miserable calumnies must be found—must disappear—a cell in Vincennes first, and then a file of Grenadiers. Find him for me, and I will not say what I will do for you, Desmarets. (He walks up and down, rapidly turning over the pamphlet)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside)Ha, ha, ha!—I think I know—ha!—it stings, it stings! (he chuckles, and rubs his hands)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Abominable! (to himself)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside)Excellent! (aloud) Oh! atrocious!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Infamous!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside)Beautiful! (aloud) Horrible!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (stopping short, and flinging down the pamphlet)Mons. Desmarets, I can dispense with a chorus. You have ordered De Cevennes to attend me here?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Yes—at half-past seven. 'Tis close on the time.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: And have you prepared his false dispatches?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: They are here, expressing your great anxiety to conclude the Emperor's marriage with the Arch-Duchess Marie Louise!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: And the real ones, communicating my negotiations in favor of the match with Russia?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Here, as you directed, in the inside of the bonbons in this box. (shews box—noise of carriage) Hark!— a carriage! (goes cautiously to window, and looks out) It is De Cevennes!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Good!—another lesson for you, Desmarets. Fools make the best agents, provided they are skilfully hood-winked!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside)I'll make a note of that for future use. Shall I retire?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Yes.Fouche goes up, and unfastens door. Desmarets retires by secret passage, with box and papers. Fouche unlocks the door, C.Enter the Marquis De Cevennes, ushered in by Jabot.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: Monsieur le Marquis De Cevennes. (Fouche, who has taken up his breviary, and appears absorbed in it, lifts his head, rises and bows)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Leave us, my son. (Exit Jabot R.)(Fouche watches him out and locks the door) You were summoned here in the name of the Police. You did not expect to be received by one in this costume: You know the cowl does not always make the monk! I am Fouché.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (stammering)I am charmed to have the honor of making such an acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Monsieur De Cevennes, you are a man of the world (De Cevennes bows) so am I. You wish to know why you are summoned here! I will tell you. Your intrigues with the exiled family are discovered.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (confused)Sir!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Do not interrupt me. A word from me would consign you to Vincennes for life.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Sir, pardon me and I will confess all!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Let me see first what there is to confess. (he reads from a paper very rapidly) On the 6th you obtained a passport for Ostend on pretence of sea bathing—you travelled by post in a green caléche without arms—dined at Amiens, and complained of the amount of your bill—you then purchased a woodcock pie—for refreshment in the carriage I presume—slept at Montreuil, and swore at the damp sheets—arrived at Ostend on the 9th—had an interview with Mons. Delbecq, agent for facilitating the passage of the Bourbonists to England—were landed by him on the beach near Dover at 8 p.m., after suffering much from sea sickness—proceeded next morning to Hartwell—had an interview with the exiled Louis XVIII., at which you presented a statement of services, professed devotion, and asked for a Dukedom.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Good gracious! All known! But I was alone with the King.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Mons. de Blacas was in the room. When two persons are together I generally know what passes, when three invariably.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You subsequently assured Mons. de Blacas that Napoleon Buonaparte was the man most detested by all classes in France—

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Oh, no! your grace—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Except the wretch Fouché! Thank you, Mons. De Cevennes.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: But I assure you—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: One moment—where was I? “Except the wretch Fouché!” Shall I go on, or can your confession add anything to this tolerably complete detail?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! as you are omniscient, be merciful. If the devotion of a life—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: That is a kind of devotion I have not, hitherto, found very available.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: If my gratitude—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p:
In my experience, fear is a more efficacious stimulus. Listen; I have need at the Austrian Court of a
trusty envoy—(De Cevennes bows) a man of high rank— (De Cevennes bows again) and of polished manners. (De Cevennes bows still lower) I offer you the mission.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I fly—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You had better receive your instructions first. You are among Madame de Fontanges' guests to-night. (De Cevennes bows) In an hour a carriage will be waiting in that courtyard, furnished with money, passports, and all that is necessary for a rapid and uninterrupted journey to Prague. You will stop at the Kaiser Karl Hotel, and ask for Madame Schoenbrunn. You will be shewn to a lady masked. You will deliver to her these despatches, (giving them) and return at once, without pushing curiosity or gallantry further.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I will be as mute as a fish and as cold blooded.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: And—yes, I think I may trust you so far—you will also present to that lady a bonbonnière from Mons. Lenoir. Remember the name.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Mons. Lenoir. It is engraved, Monsieur, here, (touching his forehead) as your clemency and confidence are here (touching his heart)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: And this is the suspicious and double-dealing Fouché! Confess, your friends of the Faubourg St. Germain do us injustice, marquis.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I will undeceive them. Oh! your grace, I have been so ill requited for my services to the Royal Family. Here is my statement of them, I presented it six times without any effect to the King, I mean the exile. If you think it would serve me with the Emperor—(shews a paper, Fouche catches sight of it)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Let me see your memorial.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (gives it)Modestly but firmly expressed—is it not?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside)The same hand. (to him) Perfect alike in style and calligraphy. Your own composition?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (simpering)Yes.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: And your own hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: No—copied by my Secretary, a young man, a native of Guadaloupe, where his father was Governor, under Louis XV.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (aside)He charged me to keep his name and arrival a secret. (aloud) His name?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Yes, I wish to make a note of it, for employment in my bureau. Such a writer ought to be at once laid hold of.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (aside)What a chance for him! (aloud) His name is Henry de Neuville.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: So!—de Neuville!—Guadaloupe!—(he reflects a moment) Like yourself, an adherent of the Bourbons, I presume?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: A rash young man; but one, I have no doubt, whose eyes may be soon opened to the error of his ways.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: As your's have been. I should like to see him. Bring him with you to-night; but remember that, in this house, I am not Fouché, the Duke of Otranto, but the Abbé Lenoir.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I pledge you the honour of a De Cevennes; and when did a De Cevennes succumb to either fear or temptation?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (who has unlocked the door, goes up stage)Enough, enough—I know precisely what one De Cevennes is worth, and by him I estimate the value of the family! (bows)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I will be punctual to a minute. (aside) Decidedly, one of the most agreeable persons I have ever met. Exit de Cevennes, C.

sp.speaker: Fouche.
sp.p: (eagerly comparing the paper given him by De Cevennes with the paper given him by Desmarets)Line for line, and letter for letter, the same!Desmarets enters noiselessly by secret door, and watches, R.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I have this bravo of the pen—this stabber of reputations. To-night he shall sleep in Vincennes! (turns and sees Desmarets) I did not call.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (R. C.)But I heard the door close, and I knew I was wanted! I have not yet got through my despatches.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: They will keep, Desmarets—they will keep! (exultingly) You look astonished!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I am not accustomed to see you indulge in the vulgar emotions of joy or sorrow.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You are right. A Minister of Police, under the Emperor, cannot afford the luxury. Look here, my old friend—here! (holds up the two writings) There, Desmarets, what say you to that?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Eh!—I do not perceive—(with some confusion)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Where are your eyes? The characters are identical to the turn of a hair stroke—and more, I know the writer,—and more than that, he will be here in half-an-hour!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (agitated)Indeed!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You do not seem to relish this discovery. (suspiciously) Ah! I see—you can't bear that I should have made it, instead of yourself; but enough, I feel I hold him fast. Order a coach here at nine—a gendarme in disguise on the box. Plant a double file of mounted gendarmes in the stable, who will take their posts on either side when the prisoner is in the carriage; and resist to the death any attempt at escape between this and Vincennes. Let that coach take its place to the right of the court-yard; the carriage to convey De Cevennes to Prague, to the left. I will write a letter to the governor of the fortress, from your cabinet. You will wait here to receive Madame de Fontanges—why, Desmarets, you look confounded!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Your excitement stupifies me!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: It is unworthy of me, I admit it; but the Minister is but a man; he must be allowed his moments of weakness. Exit Fouche by secret door.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: De Neuville discovered—arrested! will he have mettle to resist and keep the secret? Should he turn coward and purchase pardon by discovering that it is from one of Fouché's confidential agents he received the information contained in the pamphlet—should he have preserved the letter which sent it—should Fouché discover that letter came from me! He must not be arrested, or my life is not worth an old pen stump. But how to baffle Fouché? Let me see—let me see—I am as much excited as he was—I can't think coolly! (sits down and pours out glass after glass of water, which he drinks rapidly, then presses his head with his hand) Eh! yes; I have it! (flings himself back in his chair and gives a long low chuckle) Ha, ha, ha! betray his secrets—rifle his papers—release his prisoner! Ho, ho, ho! he can dispose of my place, but I can dispose of his head! Ha, ha, ha! the great Fouché at two millions a year, and the little Desmarets at four thousand francs a month! Ho, ho, ho! there is some compensation in the world, after all! (a hurried knocking at the door, L.) Come in! (opens door, L.)

div.stage: Enter Madame de Fontanges (taking off a mask as she enters; agitated and parched. L.)

sp.speaker: Madame de Fontanges.
sp.p: The Duke?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: He is busy in my cabinet; can I not supply his place?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: What money have you about you?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Money?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes, you ought to understand the word, money!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: My last month's salary was paid to-day; it is here —four thousand francs. (shews pocket-book)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Give it me—quick!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Eh! give it you?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Your master—our master, Fouché, will repay it on my order. (writes hurriedly) Here! now the four thousand francs!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Madam, I have an infinite respect for you, and the most implicit confidence in your note of hand, but you will forgive my hesitating, at least, till I know—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Till you know what I want this money for so urgently? 'Tis the old story, then, if you will have it; I have played again to-night; I have lost all, down to my bracelets—see! (holds out her arms) I want my revenge! (hoarsely) I shall win all back—I feel I shall! Quick, the money!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Madame—Madame de Fontanges, I would give you anything—everything I possess in the world—but this money I will not give you!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Insolent! you dare to refuse me?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I will not supply you with the means of ruining your beauty—your health—your happiness—your peace of mind—at the gaming-table.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Youth—beauty—peace of mind! Ha! ha! ha! (bitterly) You forget to whom you are speaking.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: To Marie de Fontanges—the daughter of a noble father, the widow of a brave gentleman, the ornament of the Faubourg St. Germain!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No, no!—that is the world's Madame de Fontanges. You speak to Marie de Fontanges, the gambler, the spy, the creature of Joseph Fouché, and, lower still—if there be a lower—of Maximilian Desmarets!—No more words; but the money, man, the money!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: You use a strange way to charm it out of my pocket.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Pshaw! Do you want me to cringe for it—to wheedle and cajole? I am low enough even for that, but do not force me.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Why will you repay with scorn my respectful interest?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Interest!—you forget to whom you are speaking.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: You have reminded me—to the gambler, the spy, the creature of Joseph Fouché.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: True, true—why will you awaken in me a pride I ought to forget?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Because I love you.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Why not? By your own showing, we are equal. But it is not that I would level you with me; I wish you to be a thing that I may look up to—that may teach me to be better myself, and to think better of others.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No more of this, Desmarets. Desperate necessities, and an absorbing passion, may have driven me to Fouché's service; the chances of the table, and some love of secret power, may keep me there. I seldom look into myself; but you almost awaken me to reason, when you show me how near I am fallen to the level of a creature like you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I am low—I know it; but love works such wonders! It will save me. It is the one spark of good left here—(touching his heart) do not trample it out—do not! (he kneels)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Miscreant! dog! slave of a slave!—stand up, or I will tread you under my feet!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Take care—I might hurt your heel. Marie, listen to me!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Silence! Oh, I hear foul words enough about the green table, and try to shut my ears to them; but I would like to remember them all, that I might pour them on your sordid head. Serpent! let go my hand! (she tears her hand away from his)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (rising, and maliciously)Ha, ha, ha!—my hand pollutes you, but you will touch my money. Here it is— bought with lies, and treachery, and blood—buy with it misery, and madness, and despair. Here, here, here! (forcing it on her)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: How dare you? Keep your money—I will not take it. (to R.) Yet, no—give it me, quick—black came up eight times running—the colour must change—I will try a martingale on red—double or quits every throw— the luck must turn—it must—or there is laudanum at the worst. Exit, furiously, L.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: So, Marie de Fontanges! “Serpent,” she said; well, serpents are grovelling things, no doubt, and proud folks tread on them, but they sting, and so does Maximilian Desmarets.Enter Fouche at secret door R.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Has Mademoiselle de Fontanges not yet returned?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Yes; from the gaming table—plucked to the last feather, as usual.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Why don't she cheat?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: She has still some scruples left; another twelve-month under your tuition may remove them. Not finding you, she has gone back for another cast of the dice.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Her passion for play will be that woman's ruin.Enter Jabot, C.

sp.speaker: Jab.
sp.p: M. De Cevennes—M. De Neuville.Enter De Cevennes and De Neuville, C.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Abbé, let me present to you my secretary, M. De Neuville; M. De Neuville, the Abbé Lenoir. (they bow)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: The unworthy confessor of Madame De Fontanges.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Pardi, Abbé! your task should be a light one, for Madame De Fontanges, the Marquis assures me, is perfect.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Perfection is not given to erring humanity; but Madame is unusually near it.—A model for her sex and a goddess for ours. (sighs and folds his hands)

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: She seems to want one virtue, however—punctuality—for here we are in the temple, but where is the divinity?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Your language is profane.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I beg your pardon. (Desmarets goes to window)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Nay, I know the warmth of a tropical temperament, and can excuse it.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I will try not to sin again; but our Creole tongues, Abbé, have a terrible trick of running away with their masters.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You will find the need of a curb in Paris, my young friend.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I will put the unruly member under your training. Luckily, here, in the Faubourg St. Germain, we are safe.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Alas! how little you know Paris! You may, even now, be surrounded by spies. May he not, M. De Cevennes?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Eh! so they say; but I don't believe it!—(aside) incredible self-command!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Well, I will promise to be rash only in the Marquis's hearing, and in yours, Abbé, and then, at least, I shall be secure!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Let us hope so; but Madame de Fontanges does not appear! I suppose I must give up my game at picquet.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: If you will allow the Marquis or myself to replace the lady for once, and then you can lecture me while we play—(he approaches a table; Jabot places card table) you will find me the most patient of penitents.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: With all my heart, my son. But you will find me a bad schoolmaster; I have too much sympathy with the openness and ardour of youth.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (who has been at the window, aside to Fouche)De Cevennes' carriage for Prague has arrived, and the coach for Vincennes. (aside)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Good! now for our game.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: If you'll allow me, I will look on.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (aside to Fouche)You can rely on him?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: As on a second self: he is one of us; come! (Fouche and De Neuville sit at the table; Desmarets and De Cevennes look on)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I conclude from your high spirits, my son, that you have not been long in Paris?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Only a fortnight! and, to tell you the truth, I am disenchanted already; I had imagined it the home of pleasure, gaiety, and wit; the theatre of noble arts, the arena of great deeds.

sp.speaker: Fouche.
sp.p: And you have found it—

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p:
The haunt of intrigue, servility, and treachery; a great prison, where every one is the gaoler of his own thoughts; a huge masquerade, but without the mirth, the music, and the champagne. I sigh for my native Guadaloupe! Oh, Abbé! if you but knew our island—its blue,
unclouded skies, its palms, and summer seas, where, though slavery surrounds us, we whites at least are free to move, and speak, and think like men.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: You are primitive in your tastes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Very! I hate laughter without joyousness; lovemaking without passion; society without confidence, and sanctimoniousness without piety. I fear I am very old-fashioned.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Oh, savage! perfectly savage!“Tytire du patulæ recubans sub tegmine fagi!”

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Yes, Paris is sadly changed; but we must pay the price of imperial glory! (shrugging his shoulders)

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: The glory of one man bought by the misery of millions! There is no true glory so purchased, Abbé. Frenchman as I am, I feel dishonoured in this man's greatness. Blood tarnishes the gold of his crown; blood stains the purple of his Imperial robe! His acquisitions are a robber's booty; his triumphs, the brutal mastery of wrong.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Hush, De Neuville! (behind table, L. C.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Let him talk—he refreshes me!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: It is most refreshing!—your card, M. de Neuville.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: And is it to this, Abbé, that the horrors of the revolution are to conduct us? Must the drunken dream of the mob end in the heavy waking of the prison house, or the bloody delirium of the battle field? No, this cannot be the end. This is a purgatory we are passing through—the glory is beyond.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside)The very style! (aloud) Ah! could we but find pens to write these truths!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Why not, if there are swords to maintain them? but the swords will come, for when were such thoughts spoken but they found echoes in a thousand breasts?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Yes, thank the spirit of old French chivalry, we have still some who dare utter all we feel. The author of those recent pamphlets, for example, signed Timon, those master-pieces of indignant eloquence—

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: What—you have read them?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I know them by heart.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (grasping his hand)If you knew the good these words do me—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I have read them too—that last, for example, against the monster Fouché.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Ah! how the wretch must have writhed!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I thought he was invulnerable to shame, as he is inaccessible to pity. Depend upon it Fouché is one of that lowest stamp of rogue, who imagines shamelessness, heroism, and consistent rascality, statesmanship. Oh, I know him well, Abbé.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I have heard him called inscrutable.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Only because few are base enough even to conceive the acts which he practices habitually. No, that pamphlet traces his career, step by step, through every doubling, from disguise to disguise, from treachery to treachery, and only leaves him, at his present post, on the right of the Imperial throne, the tricky head to guide the desperate hand. Does that pamphlet contain one word beyond the truth?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Not one.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Every document cited was authentic, for I had information—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (breaking hastily)Monsieur, you've lost a fish—two fish—four, you'll be ruined if you don't attend to your cards.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Thank you for the warning, but the subject of these pamphlets has a peculiar interest for me.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: A nearer one, young man, than it would be safe to avow here. Nay, do not start—our friend de Cevennes has hinted.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (deprecatingly)Oh, Sir!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: What, De Cevennes, you cannot have been so imprudent?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Oh! he knew his man. Do not blush. Great writer, scourge of tyranny, barer of the face of fraud, let me embrace you. (embraces him, then speaks aside over De Neuville's shoulder to Desmarets) Now!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: M. De Cevennes, have you brought with you that list of your services which you promised us?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: No, I—I left it at home, I think, on my bureau.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Careless man that you are! It is most unfortunate, as the Abbé wanted to forward it.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I will go for it with pleasure. I know the paper— I copied it only yesterday! (rises. Desmarets writes on a card unseen)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot allow you to take this trouble.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Yes, yes! If only to hide my confusion at your praises.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Stop, my coach is below; suppose you take it—the night is damp!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: A thousand thanks!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I will show it you from the window, if the fog will permit. (takes him to window) There, the fiacre on right of the entrance (quick, and aside) Take the carriage on the left—not a word! Read (giving card), before you get get in—it's life or death!

div.stage: Exit De Neuville (C.), Desmarets returns to Fouche and De Cevennes.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside to Fouche)It's done!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside to Desmarets)Excellently managed!Enter Madame de Fontanges (L.)—her manner is entirely changed—she is radiant with joyous excitement.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: At last, daughter!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: A thousand pardons, Abbé! Marquis, what penance should he impose? (aside) M. Desmarets, your money, doubled! (he takes it, and goes up L. H.)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (crosses L. to Madame)Ah, Madame! always charming—always radiant! How lovely you are to-night!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Hush, hush, or the Abbé will scold you! I have to confess to him, and your delicate compliments will oblige me to add another to my list of sins. Item—to one indulgence in feminine vanity. No, not a word will I hear! (cross to R. H. to Fouche)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Ah! cruel! (goes up L. H. to Desmarets)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (talking to Mad. de Fontanges, forward)What is the meaning of this? Desmarets tells me you have been playing again.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes, increasing your revenue, M. Fouché. Nay, don't frown at me, what would become of your secret service money, without the contributions of the gaming houses? And what would become of their contributions without me, and those like me? You see I am logical for a woman.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Woman never yet wanted logic to guide her to ruin.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ruin! Ha, ha, ha! Who first lured me to the table?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: My agents, but that was to drive you into my nets— now you are there, I wish you to avoid those places.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And our compact—do I not keep it? Do I not play your spy at those places.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: No, you get so excited by your cards that you lose your faculties of observation. Once for all, you must and shall give up play. Do you hear me?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And you tell me this—you and to-night when I have broken the bank at Petiot's—see—(thrusts her hand into her bosom, and brings it out filled with bank notes) why, man, I am independent of you for a week. (she goes up L. C.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside)It is hopeless to speak to her now. I must get her away from Paris.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (L. C. looking at the pendule)It is nine o'clock, the hour fixed for my departure. (to Fouche) M. le Duc, my time is come.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You are punctual; a good sign; your dispatches are in the carriage.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: And the bonbonnière?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Ah I had forgotten that, in weightier matters. (takes it from his pocket) There.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (taking him to the window)The carriage on the right of the entrance.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Thank you. I am infinitely obliged.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh! do not mention it Exit de Cevennes

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (throws herself into a chair L. H.)Thank Heaven that coxcomb is gone at last, I could not have borne his chatter a minute longer. I feel faint—some of that water, Duke?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (giving it to her)Fool! you see what this excitement leads to.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Do not scold me now. I cannot bear it; leave me to myself a little. I have a calculation to make (she takes a pack of cards to table and begins to combine them— marking their color with a pin on a card as they turn up.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I will stay, and stay you, Desmarets (a noise heard without) What is that? (two shots fired) The prisoner!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: He leaps from the carriage. He runs this way.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I thought my house safe—at least from this. (De Cevennes rushes in, followed by an Officer and Two Gendarmes, C.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: De Cevennes!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Save me—M. le Duc—Abbé—I mean—say it is a mistake—say I'm not the man. (down R. Desmarets speaks aside to the Officer who orders the Gendarmes They fall back respectfully. Desmarets goes off after them, C.)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: There—I said I was not the man! But they would fire, though, thanks to the fog, they missed me.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (R. C.)Now, Sir, what is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (R.)That is what I was about most respectfully to ask you.Re-Enter Desmarets. He and Fouche come forward. De Cevennes talks to Madame de F.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (R)A mistake of the carriages, owing, no doubt, to the fog. De Neuville is, by this time, beyond the barrier, on his way to Prague, in the carriage intended for M. de Cevennes!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Quick, the telegraph!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I thought of that, but unfortunately the fog is too thick for the telegraph to work.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Baffled! Confusion!—Desmarets, this is your bungling.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (shrugging his shoulders)I really cannot undertake to control the fog.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: By to-morrow morning pursuit will be in vain— nothing can stop him!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: What a pity it is I had made such perfect arrangements that the Marquis's journey should be uninterrupted!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Marquis De Cevennes, this will cause a day's delay in our plan; but be ready to start to-morrow. (he reflects)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Certainly, M. le Duc; but I do hope you will give the gendarmes orders to be a little more particular about firing. Madame, I have the honour. Exit De Cevennes, C.(Madame de Fontanges has returned to her occupation with the cards.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Your plan, Desmarets?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: He will be on friendly territory at Prague—it won't do to carry him off by force.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I know an infinity of schemes that won't do—tell me one that will.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Suppose you sent her (pointing to Mad. de Fon.) to draw him back to Paris—she is a stranger to him and she has attractions, till you know her? (aside) Ho, ho, ho! my proud lady won't like that task, I think.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: A good thought! (he touches her on the shoulder) Madame, your health is evidently impaired by the excitement of Paris—you require change of air! A young gentleman has just succeeded in escaping from Paris, whom it is essential I should have brought back again.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what is that to me?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You must follow him to Prague, where he has taken refuge; and employ those charms which are so irresistible when you like to exert them, to attract him again to Paris.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No! I have been your spy, but I will not be your decoy. (rises and crosses R.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: As a request is insufficient, I regret to change it into an order.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And I must meet that order by a refusal. Oh, I know you can imprison me—torture me—murder me, perhaps—I shall not be the first, I have not forgotten Pichegrue and Cadoudal!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: They were state criminals; but, my dear Madam, when did you ever know me rude to a lady? No, you are free to refuse—do so, and to-morrow I have you proclaimed in every drawing-room of Paris as the paid agent of the police —the salaried spy of Fouché.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You will not. You cannot have the heart to put this choice upon me. You know me for what I am, but still I have a high place and fair fame in the world. I will be your slave—your unquestioning tool in all besides this—but do not set me between such business and such dishonor.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Choose!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I know you cannot feel respect for me, but there may be some women in the world you reverence or love —a mother, a sister, or a wife. If there be, think of her, and spare me. Do—do—only in this—only in this!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Choose!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: He is pitiless!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I give you five minutes. (takes out his watch—a pause)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon,
sp.p: Better face my own conscience than the world. I will go—(she faints)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I thought she would!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside)I hoped she would not. (Moves towards the bell)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Do not alarm the servants—a glass of water!

div.stage: (Desmarets brings one—Fouche leisurely sprinkles her brow)

div.head: Act II.
div.stage: Scene.—A prettily furnished room in a cottage, overlooking the Elbe and the city of Prague; large French windows, practicable, open on a spacious terrace, with a balustrade and vases of flowers; a light verandah, covered with creepers, shades it from the sun. R., a door leading to Madame de Fontanges' dressing room; door L., leading to the entrance to the cottage from without. Rustic, but elegant furniture, books, flowers. &c., on embroidery frame. Cecile in a great chair, with work in her hand, stretching and yawning. Cloak, &c., on couch.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p:
Oh, dear! oh, dear! what a length these German days are, to be sure! I suppose it's because one measures time by laughs in Paris, and by yawns in Prague. Two months have we been here—two months with nothing to look at but those stupid trees, and flowers, and clouds, and that great, long, lazy river, run—running, shine—shine— (yawning) shining in the sun all the day long! Whatever could bring Madame to a place like this? Prague! as if anybody in their senses ever went to Prague (takes a long stretch) and she pretends to enjoy it, too! To be sure, she has M. de Neuville to make love to her, and very nicely he makes it. And I've nobody but that stupid Karl, who
makes nothing but hay. Madame could not bring a valet from Paris, so we took Karl with the cottage. Enter Grisboulle, D. L. He's dreadful—doesn't even talk, only snorts! and he's always at your elbow when you're not thinking of him!

sp.speaker: Grisboulle.
sp.p: (L.)Note! (holds out letters)

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: (R.)Oh, Lord! (starts) there he is! Good morning, Karl.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Note!

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Oh! for Madame, from M. de Neuville! I wondered we had been a whole day without seeing him! He hasn't spent much time in his own little cottage since he made Madame's acquaintance! I never saw a poor young man more in love, but Madame doesn't treat him as I should treat such a lover. (Grisboulle retires and busies himself with the flower vases on the terrace) She is wearing his life out. They've had a tiff, and this note's to make it up again. Coquette that she is! never satisfied but when she's flirting with somebody! I wish I'd anything to flirt with— Karl does not know how—and he won't learn. Karl— (tenderly) Karl.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: (gruffly)Eh?

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: What are you about, Karl?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Flowers.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Will you make me a bouquet, Karl? (insinuatingly)

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Can't.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: There! was there ever!—(shrugs her shoulders) Shall I teach you, Karl?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: No. Exit, D. L.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Dear, dear! one might as well try to amuse one's self with a German Primer. “Ach,” “Och,” “Ich!” all in grunts of one syllable. But here comes Madame. Enter Madame de Fontanges from the terrace A note, Madame, from M. de Neuville.

sp.speaker: Mad de Fon.
sp.p:
So: you may go, Cecile. (Gives hat to Cecile: who puts it on couch, and exit, L.) He has been playing truant for the last twenty-four hours, and this explains his absence, I suppose. Poor fellow! I fear my dart has pierced rather deeper into that bare bosom
than into the well-padded chests of my Parisian adorers. The vehemence of his passion startles me sometimes. It is his tropical temperament, I suppose. The sun, which has bronzed his cheek, may have enriched his blood and quickened his susceptibilities, but can it make nature truer, or affection more constant? No! he may be as changing and hollow as the rest. If you could but believe in man, what a glorious thing love would be! The few tranquil weeks I have spent here, since by a simple artifice I made his acquaintance, I really think have been the four happiest of my life. I have not once missed the excitement of the cards! Strange! in playing with his heart, there have been moments when his earnestness has shot a sudden thrill through me which I never felt before. If it were the first stir of love! Pshaw! let me remember what I am, and what I have to do! I wish Fouché had found another instrument. But his note. (she opens it and reads) “Madame—” Madame! we are distant this morning, Monsieur—“If I listened to the promptings of my heart I would not begin thus coldly—” listen to them, Monsieur! happy you if you hear anything— “but I dare not, and yet I cannot stifle them. I love you madly—” poor fellow! “with a passion violent like my nature, but reverential as my worship of that saint whose sweet name you bear—” pretty! “my love is so real, so ungovernable—you must have seen it—” What were eyes given us for? “and yet you will not deal with me as a true-hearted woman should.” Alas! if truth and heart both be wanting! “I would live for you—die for you—and you but trifle with me. Either tell me I am indifferent to you, and then I will go and wrestle with my grief alone, or show, by a tenderness like my own, that you are worthy of as true a devotion as ever man felt for woman.” (she pauses) “I have struggled with myself the whole night through before writing this—I am almost mad. If I am too bold, forgive me—for I cannot live out of your sight: may I come for your answer.—Henri de Neuville.” (she sits and lets the letter fall on her lap) If it should be true that his heart is of a different mould from those that till now have found their best use as my playthings, what a terrible task is this I am about? I will go no further with it! But Fouché's orders are irrevocable; and, alone as I am here, so far away from Paris, I feel as if his cold relentless eye was on me at every turn.
Who knows? this man may after all be only a more consummate actor than the rest! This show of rough sincerity may be art. No, no! I feel in my inmost self that he is true and noble! To win such a heart might make any woman proud; but to win it on a cold, passionless calculation—to win it that I may place it under the point of Fouché's stiletto! Oh! foul, foul! The more noble it is, the more hideous is my treachery! What is to be done?Enter Henri de Neuville, by terrace, L. H.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Your pardon, Madame, if I have come without a summons—You have read my letter?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes, M. de Neuville, and shall I tell you the truth?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Tell me nothing but the truth always.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: The tone of it is new to me.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: It may be, for it is the voice of a real, a devoted love—the love of a man who has never felt before what it was to hang with all his being upon the breath of another. Till now I have shared the hopes, and fears, and projects of my party, of those who looked to the restoration of our rightful King. But now ambition, projects, plots, hopes, fears, all are dead within me—my life, my soul are yours!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (restraining herself)I believe you feel all this now, but who can answer for himself a week hence? Love! Who that knows the changefulness of the weather and the fashions can believe in the eternity of anything, much less of love, which we change oftener than an April day, or a spring bonnet.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I cannot believe her frivolous who awakens in me what I feel.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: At least do not conclude too soon. I shall soon return to Paris, and absence will test your devotion.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Absence! You do not think I can leave you?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Nay, it is impossible you can return to Paris, where Fouché threatens your liberty—indeed your life!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p:
Ha! so danger is to deter me! Go, go! that you may see if I will follow—aye, though Fouché's spies
were ranged at every barrier, and I must run the gauntlet of them all! But why return to Paris? You are free. Our positions are equal. I offer you my hand for the hundredth time! Oh, make me happy with yours, and we will live here in an exile that we shall bless, because in it we shall be all in all to each other!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (aside)This is real! And shall I be his destroyer? Forgive, me M. de Neuville, if I have appeared sometimes to trifle with you, but there are obstacles which even with love on both sides cannot be surmounted.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Obstacles! Name them, that I may prove to you they are none.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Suppose I were to say I will never marry —that I find the liberty of widowhood too agreeable?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I would not believe you. Give me a better reason.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You have grave duties to your party— duties which love distracts you from. Till your King is restored to France you have no right to chain your destinies to a woman.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: The King was first in my heart till I knew you— now he is second. A better reason still. Do you love another? De Cevennes has boasted—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: He! Oh, no; my heart is free! But why force me to say there are motives—I regard you too much to tell you them. Do not ask me, if you would still love me as you say you do.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Oh, why will you not lay bare your heart to me, as I do mine to you?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: How do you know that I have one?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: By the colour that mounts to your cheek when I speak to you of love; by the languor that veils your eyes when we sit together and watch the sunset in a silence too passionate for speech; by the trembling of your voice when we bid each other farewell; by the thrill that shoots from my being to yours, from yours to mine, when our hands meet, or a tress of your hair brushes my cheek. By these signs, and the thousand subtler that a lover's eye can see but no tongue can describe, so delicate are they—you have a heart, Marie de Fontanges, and that heart is mine! (he seizes her hand)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p:
(overcome)Henri, my own! (starts back
from his embrace) Sir, you forget yourself! you have no right to put my nervous susceptibility to the proof of such excellent acting.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Acting!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes: do not talk to me, after that tirade of your inexperience. Talma might take a lesson from you. I remember uttering just such a scream after his grand burst in “Orestes.”

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Oh, you will drive me mad! (starting up)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No, no; but seriously, (sits) are you wise in yielding to this passion for one you scarcely know? Why, I may be an adventuress—who knows? an emissary of Fouché's, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: No; the instincts of such a love as mine are infallible;—it would shrink up at the contact of baseness as the sensitive plant at a touch! I know you as if I had watched your actions from a child;—I know you as your own conscience knows you!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Hush—hush, Henri!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Oh! let me throw myself where the slave should be—at his tyrant's feet; where the worshipper should be —prostrate before his saint. (he throws himself at her feet) Let me but lie thus, and look up into your eyes, and rest my brow upon your hands, and forget time, duty, danger, all in the delirious happiness of my love! (he suits the action to the word)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh, Henri! check this passion—you must; it is not that my heart is cold to it. If I durst listen to its promptings!Enter Cecile, C., comes down R. Henri rises.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: A gentleman, Madame—oh, I beg pardon!— who gave his card. (aside) Very pretty!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: M. Lebon. (aside) Desmarets! (rises and goes to L.)

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: My preserver! Oh, shew him in here, Cecile, at once! Exit Cecile, C. and L. I long to see and thank him. He saved me, Marie, on that night I was to have been arrested from your house.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (aside)Fouché distrusts me. The task-master is sent to overlook the slave. It is too late!

div.stage: Enter Cecile shewing in Desmarets, C. from L.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: M. Lebon. Exit Cecile, R.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Being on my way from Vienna, whither a little money affair took me, I ventured to pay my respects to Madame.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (bows)You are at home in my house, Sir, as you know.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: You are too kind!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Failing Madame de Fontanges, you have a sacred right of asylum with me, M. Lebon; you remember me?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah, M. de Neuville!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Your timely warning saved me on the night Fouché was to have arrested me. I have bewildered myself in endeavouring to discover a clue to the treachery which betrayed me. Can you explain it?

sp.speaker: Des.
Neuv.
sp.p: Say, rather, all treacheries and all basenesses! But here I can defy him. Spies cannot breathe the air of purity and peace that bathes these blue hills, and scarce ripples that placid river. I only think of him as of an adder, whose spring I have escaped, and whose hisses I laugh at. (takes up a flower) But how came you to be warned of my danger?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh! one of his creatures, the wretched Desmarets, had a scruple of conscience, or rather some fear for his own safety, which led him to reveal the plot to me, that I might warn you.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: By the bye—what interesting documents that last pamphlet of yours brings to light. How did you procure them?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: From an unknown correspondent, one evidently having access to the archives of the Police.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: You have, of course, preserved the letters transmitting them?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: No! fearing they might some day endanger my unknown informant, I burnt every scrap I ever received from him.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (aside)I am safe! Ah, that's a pity; you might, in case of danger, have purchased safety by denouncing him.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: M. Lebon, that is a counsel no gentleman would take. I am surprised any gentleman should give it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah! you have the chivalry of youth, I the caution of riper years;—but this conversation is not interesting to Madame.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Pardon me! all that concerns Fouché has a strange fascination for me.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh! I could tell you stories of him that would horrify you! Conceive his employing a troop of wretched, degraded women, whom he calls his “Cohorte Cythérienne,” to attract his victims within his reach—and they do it, too

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Can there be women so base?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (aside)Viper! (aloud) Before we condemn, we should know the arts by which he has enslaved them. Once enslaved, it may be they are powerless.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: But surely death would be preferable to such baseness?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Death!—Yes! But he can disgrace these women; reveal their shame to the world—nay, worse—to those they love, and who love them! What death is so sharp as that?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Poor creatures—poor creatures! They are much to be pitied. I pity them, especially when I think there may be haughty beauties among them, who have been used to despise others.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (aside) He chafes me to distraction! (aloud to De Neuville) M. Lebon is a stranger to our valley, M. de Neuville; will you show him the lovely prospect from these hills?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: With pleasure, if M. Lebon will accept me for a guide; but I warn you it is rough climbing.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Never fear, I've a strong sense of the picturesque.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: But have you a strong pair of legs? You have— eh? Then come along; I'll show you every sight worth seeing within a league round (aside to Mad. de F.) and dream of you dearest, at each point where we have sat together.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Au revoir, Madame! Exeunt Desmarets and de Neuville by the Terrace.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes, the mask is off at last! I see my hideous self! And he thinks me pure! The sincerity of his own nature reflects itself on mine! What an awakening, should he learn the truth! And Desmarets, malignant as he is, will soon find out I love him. What is to be done? Fouché alone can relieve me from this task, which, base always, is now a sacrilege; for I love him—love him as he is worthy to be loved—love him with my whole soul! Yes! I will write to Fouché. Enter Desmarets by Terrace. I feel a power within me that will work even upon him. I will write at once! (as she turns for writing materials her eye falls on Desmarets—she stands staring at him, then sinks into a seat) You here again!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I have despatched M. de Neuville into Prague for my calêche. Let me congratulate you, Madame, on the restorative effects of the Austrian air. You look so much better,—that is—you did until you saw me. You were going to write to Fouché—pray write—unless you think I can save you the trouble.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: He has sent you down here?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Yes; he was naturally anxious about your health, and he sent me to enquire—merely to enquire. He was also anxious to know how our little ruse was succeeding— when we might expect to see the Siren wing her flight back to Paris, with her captive in her clutch.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: M. Desmarets, I have lived a new life since that promise was made. I cannot keep it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah—M. Fouché will be sorry to hear it. He is so particular about promises, so very particular—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Sir, you have pofessed an interest in me; if you retain a spark of that interest still, release me from the degrading task to which M. Fouché has condemned me.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Listen to me, Marie de Fontanges. I am not young, not pleasant to look at; I have no graces of speech; I am what the world calls a spy, an informer—what you will that is more ignoble and treacherous; but I have a will like iron, and a head which, under any other chances, might have made a different man of me. Till I knew you, all my species were alike to me—counters to be pushed about as suited my game; but at sight of you I felt that you were my fate—my good angel, if you chose to be so!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh! no, no! we are our own good and evil angels.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Let me finish. You spurned me once in a fashion that few men of a less determined spirit would provoke or endure twice. Yet I provoke it again, for proud as you are I love you still!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh! no, no!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I love you still! There is but one way to save you from Fouché—it is by sacrificing him! Give me but hopes that time will change your scorn of me to endurance—leave me to change endurance into pity, and pity into love. From the day which gives me that hope, Joseph Fouché's fall and your rescue are both begun!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: This from you! I thought you were devoted to him?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh, so I am—so I am!—ha, ha, ha! but my devotion never stands in the way of my will—never!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: But surely it is madness in you to dream of striking at one placed so high and seated so securely?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho! (chuckles) A small worm may sink a big ship! Listen!—

sp.speaker: Cevennes
sp.p: (without)At least you can announce me, my taciturn friend. The Marquis de Cevennes—de Cevennes!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: That fool! Will you see him?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No, no; not now!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: He is here—we will resume this conversation when he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (going to her room)Oh, Sir, have pity on me! Exit into her room, R.Enter De Cevennes C. from L., shown in by Grisboulle.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: He is certainly the man of the fewest words I ever— Ah! Madame not here, eh? The excellent M. Lebon, (De Cevennes carries in his hand a common stout walking-stick with a silver head) one of our party on that eventful night when I was so highly honoured and so nearly shot. You have not forgotten me?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Few that meet the Marquis de Cevennes can forget him.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p:
Ah, Monsieur, you are very polite! Yes, it was a delightful soirée—that is, all but the little mistake which
concluded it. Would you believe it, Sir, I've been three times to Prague and back since that eventful evening! But it's very odd—many as are the despatches I carry, I never bring back any answer—“vestigia nulla retrorsum!” Not that I return empty handed, either—the ladies of the court employ me about their little commissions—give me things to carry—the oddest things, sometimes. Now, on this occasion, what do you think the Duchess von Kaiserleben gave me to take to the Duke of Otranto? Only guess?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh, I give it up!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: A stick—this stick—(holding it up) neither more nor less. Odd present from a Duchess to a Duke, is it not?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (takes it and sways it in his hand)Very; Dukes have given such things to Duchesses now and then.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: You can examine it at your leisure while I wait for Madame.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Shall I order you some refreshment?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Eh! well, really—if you can take the liberty—but shall I not see her first?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I am afraid not—she was denied to me—she is not well.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Poor creature! excitable always! Well, if I cannot see her, I think a cutlet and a bottle of Geisenheimer—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Karl! Grisboulle appears on the terrace and comes down. Karl, luncheon for the Marquis. (aside to him) Not here!

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Good! (Grisboule goes off. L,)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: A thousand apologies for the trouble. By the way, I have been so constantly on the move since the eventful evening, I have never been able to recover any trace of my secretary, M. de Neuville. You remember the young man the Duke took such a fancy to, who disappeared so mysteriously on the same eventful evening? What can have become of him?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah! from discretion, I've never inquired.

sp.speaker: Grisboulle.
sp.p: (appearing at door, L.)Lunch!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Ah! my friend of the limited vocabulary! Have you observed how very sparing he is of words?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Dis—cretion.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Yes; I have remarked the Germans are discreet.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Lunch! (Desmarets makes him a signal)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I'm coming, my abrupt friend, I'm coming. (as he goes off looking at him) A most repulsive physiognomy! Exit De Cevennes, L.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: The chattering ape has left behind him the only thing worth a thought—this stick. Ah! he little knew I turned it! (he screws off the head of the stick, which is hollow, and draws out a roll of paper) The answer to Fouché's last dispatch, which went, by the way, in a paté of snipe. (opens paper) Why will Joseph not trust his old friend? Why will he force him to this sort of thing? (looks at paper) So, Joseph: more counterplotting the Emperor, and in his marriage, too! He wants a Austrian wife and you insist on giving him a Russian one. Have a care, Joseph, have a care. It's a game of heads, Joseph, and thine totters, Joseph, totters! totters!—Karl!Enter Grisboulle, L.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: A fac-simile of this paper immediately.

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Good! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: A very valuable man, Grisboulle. He can assume any disguise, copy any handwriting, drink any quantity of wine, and never goes beyond monosyllables.Enter Madame de Fontanges, D. R.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Has the Marquis gone?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: No; but he is at table, where, as I don't hear him chattering, I conclude his teeth are employed. Let me resume the conversation he interrupted.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You ventured to threaten Fouché!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I never bark when I cannot bite! Papers of his are in my hands that would condemn him were he ten times Fouché!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And he knows this?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: A man must trust somebody! He has trusted me! Ho, ho, ho!—And I will trust you! I contrived the place of deposit for these very papers. You know the picture on the left of your drawing-room?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
Press the third ornament on the right side of the
frame; the picture moves and discovers a passage. It leads from my house to yours.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Touch the rosette of the third panel in that passage—it slides away. In the recess stands the box containing Fouché's treasonable correspondence with Bernadotte, with Murat, with all who have an interest in the Emperor's death, or hopes of sharing the spoil of his downfall; there, too, are the Emperor's private letters and instructions, the bulwark to which Fouché trusts when all else fails him. Madame de Fontanges, I have given you my secret. I have put into your hands the master-key to my life and fortunes; you know my secret!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (reflects)Your secret is safe with me!Grisboulle enters silently, C., and unseen by Madame de Fontanges, lays paper on table and exit, with look at Desmarets, noiselessly.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I have surrounded Fouché himself with the meshes of my police. He is inquisitor over France. I am inquisitor over him. (takes papers Grisboulle has left) See here, this is a secret despatch which that ass, De Cevennes, is bearer of without knowing it. That was never intended to come to my knowledge; yet here is a fac-simile of it, which goes to Fouché, while I retain the original. (he places fac-simile in stick) You see I shew you my cards!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And having overthrown Fouché, you would aspire to his post?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: If alone, yes; if with you, no. I will go where you bid me—be what you will—if you will not refuse the endurance, which is all I ask, in return for restoring you to honour and happiness?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (R. C.)Give me some time for reflection!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh, certainly! certainly! Weigh my offer well. I will wait for your answer before I return to Paris. Work with me if you will—betray me if you dare! Exit by Terrace, L.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p:
He dare attack Fouché to serve his ambition! Shall I fear him to save my love? These secrets! Without betraying him I might use them to extricate myself and to save Henri. Desmarets does not know I love
Henri; he must not see us together! I must fly to Paris without leaving any trace of my route. There I will see Fouché, and, failing prayers, this secret must serve me against him. But how to leave this place undiscovered?—

sp.speaker: Cevennes.
sp.p: (without)My carriage at once!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ha! his carriage!Enter De Cevennes, D. L.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Ah! Madame, this is indeed happiness. I was going away a heart-broken prilgrim without a sight of the fair saint of my pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: A truce to compliments, Marquis; it is important I should return to Paris speedily and secretly.— Will you give me a seat in your calêche?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Ah Madame! the felicity will be overpowering. (aside) Dis-cretion!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I will meet you at the turn of the road. Not a word to any one!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Not even to that dear M. Lebon?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: To him least of all.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I fly, a happier man in every respect. (aside) A perpetual tête átête with a lovely creature all the way to Paris! Exit De Cevennes, C. and L.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Yes, I will go—but Henri, what will he think of this departure? Oh! I cannot leave him:—and yet, with Desmarets here, I dare not risk a parting, or our love will be known, and with it, my infamy. Yes, I must go for his sake; and, once at Paris, I may save him, and free myself from the sword which is always hanging over my head. Yes, though my heart break, I must leave you, Henri!—And yet, to go without one word! No—no—I cannot —(she writes a note hastily and leaves it on the table) And now, dear home, where I have first known peace and love, good bye—good bye—good bye! (she throws herself down and buries her face in a chair, then rising, looks passionately about her. Then, after tying on her hat, takes a flower from one of the vases and exits hurriedly along terrace and R.)Enter Desmarets, C.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
Ah! not here.
Enter Cecile door R. Where is your mistress?

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Out, I suppose, Sir.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: She has not passed out by the Terrace.

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: All I know is, she's not in her room.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Where can she be? Enter Grisboulle, C. I'm in a cold sweat till she pronounces her decision. Ah! here's one who will know something. Where is Madame?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Gone?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Gone! with no word for me?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: (seeing note on table)Note! (gives it R.)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (looking at address)For me?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (reads address)M. de Neuville!! (reads) “Farewell! I leave this place—perhaps for ever. Ask not why or whither—I love you passionately. But I must leave you.—Marie.” Gone!—by what means?

sp.speaker: Gris.
sp.p: (at Terrace) Look! (Desmarets turns up and looks out) Exit Grisboulle.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: De Cevennes' carriage stops at the turn of the road —a woman gets in—it is she! The carriage starts again at full gallop!

sp.speaker: Cecile.
sp.p: Gone! (she runs off, D. R.)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
Oh! fool that I was to leave my calêche at Prague! She carries my secret with her! My fortune—my life may depend on my outstripping them to Paris. But this note to De Neuville!—“I love you passionately!” Can she really love him? Then her listening to me was a trick to worm my secret out of me, and then use it for herself. I see it all, all now! Oh! gull, idiot that I am! She loves him, and so flies to escape the revelation of her infamy face to face. What hinders me from revealing it to him still? Or shall I keep the secret and let him follow her to Paris? Were he brought there, Fouché's end would be gained. He has burnt my letters. I have nothing to fear from his arrest now. Yes, it shall be done—he shall follow her to Paris. She has gone with De Cevennes—ah! jealousy—jealousy!—
I will destroy him, reveal her shame, and break two hearts —all at one blow. Ho! ho! ho! 'Tis a revenge might satisfy Bëlzebub, or Fouché himself.Enter De Neuville C. from L. in joyous excitement, speaking as he enters.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: M. Lebon, your calêche will be here in ten minutes; I saw it brought out, and the horses harnessed I am sorry you leave us so soon, and so will Madame D. Fontanges be, I am sure; but at least you must not go without a stirrup cup. Here, Karl—wine! Cecile, tell Madame M. Lebon is going.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Madame is gone herself!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: What do you mean? Gone!—Where?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Nobody knows.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Surely she has left some word—some letter—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Nothing!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: But when—how did she go?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Just now—in the carriage with the Marquis De Cevennes.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: The Marquis De Cevennes!—(he stands aghast) gone with De Cevennes! What can this mean? With De Cevennes, my friend?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: 'Tis the privilege of friends at Paris.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
Des.
sp.p: Forget her.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Forget her! Old man, she has grown a part of me—to tear out her image. I must tear out my heart-strings with it! Oh! to know what road they have taken!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: We have no chance of overtaking them.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: We have!—What speed can outstrip revenge?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Revenge!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Do you think that when one of my blood is so wronged, he that wrongs him is allowed to live? (crosses to L. He is going)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: My carriage will be here immediately. It is at your service. We will go together.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Thanks, my friend, thanks!—but, their route, their route? How to discover that? No matter, the instinct of revenge will guide me—come!

sp.speaker: Karl.
sp.p: I know. (stop, C.)

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Ah! their road!—speak! speak!

sp.speaker: Karl.
sp.p: To Paris.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: To Paris! to Paris!—Quick!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Think of the danger. Arrested by Fouché on French soil you are a dead man!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Death may be there, but revenge is by its side. I want that first: then let death come! To Paris, to Paris!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: He is mine! (following De Neuville L. U. E.)

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Scene as in Act I. - Night - stage dark - candles unlighted on table, R.C. and mantelpiece.
Enter Madame de Fontanges shown in by Jabot, C. D., who is in dressing gown and has a lantern in his hand.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: (R. C.)A thousand excuses, Madame, for having kept you at the door.

sp.speaker: Madame de Fontanges.
sp.p: Enough, my good Jabot, I accept them; I was not expected.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: I had retired unusually early.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No more apologies; light the candles and leave me.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: Madame—(hesitating)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Well, why do you not light them?

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: A thousand pardons, Madame, but—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (feeling for and finding them)Here they are!

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: Yes; but Madame will understand—I am not in a fit state; I ask pardon—but my—my deshabille; I am not fit to appear—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (laughing)Oh, my poor Jabot!—I understand—leave your lantern—I will light the candles.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: You are too good, Madame; you have relieved my mind. You require nothing more, Madame?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Nothing, Jabot. Good night!

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: I have the honour—(bows)—In two minutes I will be prepared to appear before you, as propriety requires.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Do not come unless I ring. Exit Jabot, C.(Madame de Fontanges lights the candles hastily.) By good fortune, and the Marquis's liberality to the postillions, we have reached Paris before Desmarets. While De Cevennes slept, I have extracted the fac-simile of the secret despatch from the cane. It is another arm against Fouché. Now to secure the papers Desmarets described— with them I may conquer Fouché at his own weapons! He shall find I have not served in his school for nothing! (goes towards picture and feels for the spring) The spring should be in this ornament—(she feels for it)—yes, the picture yields! (The picture moves away and discovers the entrance of the passage with Fouche in it, a dark lantern in his hand) Fouché! (the candle she holds begins to tremble in her hand from the violence of her agitation—Fouche remains calm and unmoved)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: The candlestick is too heavy for your hand, Madame, allow me to relieve you of it. (he takes the candlestick from her, and puts it on the table—aside) A minute sooner and she would have found me at the recess! (to her) You are agitated; pray sit down and compose yourself.
