(she sits mechanically L. of table. Aside) Can she know anything? (aloud) I was not aware you had the secret of that passage.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I discovered it by an accident. (hesitatingly)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p:
(aside)I told Desmarets it was unsafe. (aloud) I ought to apologize for making such a breach in your party
wall without notice, but I have such an objection to being announced, and I hate front doors.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You have reason.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (sits R.)You seemed startled to see me?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I did not know—(pause)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Oh! my visit then is an unexpected pleasure—not so yours! (aside) What can have brought her back?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You knew I had left Prague?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: How else should I have been prepared to receive you?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No news could have reached you! I left suddenly, and we travelled as fast as four horses could carry us.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside)We? A companion! (aloud) Four leagues an hour is good travelling, but the telegraph beats it.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Inscrutable man! Then you know all?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Not all, precisely, but most; your travelling companion, for example.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: De Cevennes has told you?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside)So, it was he! (aloud) My dear Madame, if I gave up my sources of information I should not long hold my portfolio of the Police. Enough, that I know of your leaving Prague in company with the Marquis.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You had your spies even there! Perhaps you know my reasons for leaving?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: The reason you gave the Marquis, of course. But a lady's real reasons are beyond even my penetration. Perhaps you will favour me with them—I am all attention.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You know how I struggled against the duty you imposed upon me. (he bows) But your hold over me was too strong—(he bows again) I yielded, and set about my work—reluctantly, at first, but by degrees the devil of womanly vanity got the upper hand, and I laid siege to De Neuville's heart with all the arts that my experience of Parisian society had taught me. Impassioned and inexperienced in woman's wiles he was an easy conquest.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You see I chose my emissary well.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You did not!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Ah?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p:
You thought the hot wind of play had dried up in me all that was good or akin to good.—I thought so too.—Neither of us knew how vital the roots of love are in
a woman's nature. At contact with the fresh and springing life of his passion my dead affection wakened, till what we both thought a stone became a living, leaping, loving, woman's heart. I found him ready to follow me to the jaws of death—

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: And you did not lead him to Paris? It was a blunder!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I resolved to risk my life to save his. I knew all I exposed myself to in disobeying your orders. I knew that shame, imprisonment, perhaps death, lay in the path of duty. There they sit in you—and here (rising) stands love in me to meet and grapple with them!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (rises)You would have made a capital actress! But no heroics, pray—leave them to the theatre and Mademoiselle Georges. You have told me what brought you back; and now oblige me by explaining how you mean to conduct this struggle between shame, &c., or Joseph Fouché, and love, &c., or Marie de Fontanges?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I should not have said “struggle.” How can an unfriended woman struggle with the potent Minister of Police?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Exactly the question I wished to ask, better expressed.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I meant, after telling you the truth, to have appealed to the good I cannot believe utterly dead in you, now that it has revived in me. Ah, Fouché! think of all that virtuous love means in a woman like me—self-scorning, self-loathing, living only to be the prey of frantic excitement, or the tool of dark intrigues.—It is the branch that sweetens the bitter waters of my life—the ray that breaks upon the labours of the prisoner to tell him he has pierced the outer wall of his dungeon. Till I knew it, I had nothing to believe in—nothing to venerate—nothing to live for. Having it, a future of peace and purity opens before me. Do not darken this future! Spare him, that I may love him—far from Paris, far from plots, and intrigues, and passions. Spare him, Fouché! spare him! —and spare me! (she has risen while speaking, and now falls on her knees grasping Fouché's hand)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p:
(who has betrayed once or twice slight signs of emotion)What eloquence earnestness gives! I never could
feel in earnest, or I should have been eloquent. Rise, Madame! We will talk of this again when you are less excited.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No—now—here. I will not leave this spot till you have answered me.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I am sorry for it, as I must refuse.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Refuse! Oh you cannot!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (shrugs his shoulders)You cannot understand state reasons, or you would see I must. What would the world, say of Fouché if they heard, that having the serpent under his heel, he forbore to crush it, out of consideration for a woman's unreasonable passion. My dear Madame, I should have all the serpents hissing at once. No—once for all— it cannot be. I will listen to no more. (crossing C.)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (rising, her figure dilated)Beware! Joseph Fouché!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (turning and smiling)Eh! you spoke?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You have laughed at my love—fear my hate!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Come, this is better; your grief pained me, your rage amuses me.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Take care lest the time should come when you will sue to me.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Eh! ha, ha! Excuse my laughing, but—when shall I sue to you? Ha! ha! ha!—though you are charming enough, especially when excited, to render it not improbable.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Mocker! I tell you I have means of action against you you little dream of—I will use them—I warn you of it—ruthlessly—remorselessly—if by them alone I can save the man I love!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (aside)Can she know anything? Pshaw! a woman's bravado. (he turns and bows) Madame, I have the honor—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (crosses L.)Then we separate on my terms.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: No—on mine.—Return to Prague. Fulfil your contract, and all shall be forgotten that has occurred to-night. Refuse—and to-morrow, your connection with the Police is the topic of conversation in every salon of Paris.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Very well! Then it is war between us— war to the knife! Be it so! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p:
She has a man's courage, at all events. I rather
like her. But these threats are childish. My papers are safe —I saw them a quarter of an hour ago. It is now ten o'clock. You are mistress of the situation to-night; tomorrow it will be too late! (a ring heard) Ha! a late arrival! (looks out of window) The Marquis de Cevennes, come, no doubt, to enquire after the health of his travelling companion. He will be surprised to find me! Exit by secret door, R.Enter Jabot (dressed) shewing in De Cevennes, C.

sp.speaker: Jab.
sp.p: I will announce M. le Marquis to Madame!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Do! Say I merely wish to assure myself she has not suffered by our rapid journey, (exit Jabot, C., closing doors) or been annoyed by my attentions on the road.— A charming tête àtête!—Unluckily I was so fatigued, I slept most part of the way! Enter Fouché by the secret door unseen by De Cevennes. I will see Madame first, and then for the dear Duke!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: No; the dear Duke first, and then Madame!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (turning)Ha! the Duke here! why, how did you enter?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: My movements, like my intelligence, are rather mysterious, Marquis! But here I am.—I congratulate you on your quick return, and on your fair compagnon de voyage!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Oh! your Grace has heard! It's incredible!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (R.)You delivered your despatches?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: They required no answer. I think I may dismiss you at once to Madame.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Ah! I had almost forgotten! The Duchess Von Kaiserleben—really, 'tis too odd, too ridiculous—particularly requested me—you'll excuse the absurdity—to present the Abbé Lenoir—now don't be angry!—with this walking cane!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Give it me! (coolly taking the cane from the Marquis)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: You are not surprised?

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Never! so—a pretty cane! The handle is a souvenir. (looking at the head) See! (shows it him)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Why, I never observed before; 'tis a death's head and cross bones!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Yes; an appropriate present to me, in my spiritual capacity; very pretty and cheerful!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Remarkably! (aside) How very lugubrious!

sp.speaker: Fou.
Cev.
sp.p: Ah, your Grace! (aside) I wish, though, he'd give me a leetle time for repose between my journies; I am worn to a skeleton! Exit De Cevennes, L.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: So—and now for Czernitcheff's despatch; it should announce the final stipulations for the Russian alliance. (begins to unscrew the head of the cane) The Emperor's heart is set on the Austrian Archduchess; but my head on the Russian. Head against heart is desperate odds always! (he has unscrewed the head and has found the hollow empty) How's this? Empty? Can Czernitcheff be retreating, or has this fool discovered and abstracted the paper? No, no; it is incredible! Or can some sharper sight have penetrated the secret? I must find out, for this is a matter of life and death to me! I have gone between the lion and his prey, and have no inclination to try the weight of his imperial paw. (reflects)Re-enter De Cevennes, L.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: So now for this new mark of imperial favor, Monsieur le Duc. Madame having retired, I am at your Grace's service.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (angrily)So! Sir—this is the way you discharge your commissions! The Duchess's present has been mutilated?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Mutilated! The stick is as when I received it—upon the honor of a De Cevennes.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: The Duchess's letter, describing it, speaks of diamonds in the eyes of the skull. They have been abstracted.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: No—upon my honor!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: The stick must have quitted your hands!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Never! I kept tight hold of it all the way from Prague to Paris.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You slept in the carriage?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Not a wink—on the honor of a De Cevennes.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Then you extracted the diamonds yourself!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Oh! M. le Duc—what a slur on the honor of a De Cevennes!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: That for the honor of the De Cevennes. (crosses L. snapping his fingers) I am dissatisfied with you, Sir! I know your intrigues with the exiled family—you may need to take better care of your own head, than you have of this cane's. Look to it, Sir! And now, sit at that table and write, briefly, the stages of your journey, your places of stoppage, the persons you met. (aside) I must at once despatch another messenger to enquire into this; in the mean time, lest there should be anything in Madame's threat, there can be no harm in setting a watch to see that she does not leave the house to-night. Exit by secret door

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: (writing at L. of table, and not aware the Duke has left the room)You shall have every information, M. le Duc. (writes) “Left Prague on the 16th. at ten. Lunched at Madame de Fontanges' cottage. (aside) Shall I say I met M. Lebon? I had better tell the truth—as he knows everything. Started with Madame—he knows that too. What was the next stage? Eh! Oh! those dreadful German names I haven't the least notion how to spell Schratzenellenbogen—I must appeal to the Duke—Monsieur—M. le Duc, how do you spell—(looks round) Eh! spell—why I declare he's gone. (rising—the folding doors open) Here he comes. (he runs to table and begins to write diligently)Enter Madame de Fontanges, L.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: The doors are guarded. The Officer has orders not to allow me to quit the house! What is to be done to get this paper carried? Ha! Fouché not here, and De Cevennes alone! May I trust him? I must, Monsieur. (she comes forward)

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Eh! not the Duke! Madame, you come to save me.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Madame, for the love of mercy, how do you spell Schratzenellebogen?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Pshaw! You have seen the Duke?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I have. (dolefully)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And this new mark of imperial favor he promised you?

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: There's a hitch somewhere. In fact, I'm a disgraced—a ruined man, and it will be entirely owing to the Duke's good nature if I'm not denounced to-morrow, for my treasonable correspondence with the King. He says there are diamonds missing from the head of that cane.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Hush! there is missing from that cane what is more precious to Fouché than all the diamonds of Golconda. There needs but one quarter of an hour's resolution to enable you to save yourself and to ruin him.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Only a quarter of an hour's resolution? Madame, I am prepared for any danger—speak!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: The cane concealed a secret dispatch.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: A secret despatch!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Which I abstracted in the carriage while you slept.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: Oh, Madame! How could you?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Many lives depended on it. That paper involves Fouché in the guilt of high treason—(she produces despatch letter.) It is here. Take it instantly to the Grand Chamberlain—yes, there is a ball at the Tuïlleries to-night—he will no doubt conduct you to the Emperor. State you came from me—

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: But this letter?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Only stipulates for the safety of one who is very dear to me as the price of this intelligence. Quick! Fouché may be back every moment,—and soon, no doubt, egress from my house may be as impossible for you as it is for me. Quick! do not hesitate.—For my sake!

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: But the risk?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: For your own sake.

sp.speaker: Cev.
sp.p: I will go at once! Exit De Cevennes, C. and L.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: And now, Duke of Otranto, it is a race for life between you and me!Enter Jabot, C.

sp.speaker: Jabot.
sp.p: A gentleman to see Madame instantly. Here is his card. (giving it)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Desmarets! He here! I was just in time! And Henri—he will bring me news of Henri! Yes, admit him! (Exit Jabot, C.) Should he have betrayed to him what I am—with what intention I followed him to Prague! He is cruel enough! Oh, if I could read in his face!

div.stage: Enter Jabot, shews in Desmarets C,, and exit. Madame de Fontanges stands eagerly and keenly looking at him.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Delighted to see you once more, Madame; but you have given me a hard journey. (he takes a light from the table, goes rapidly to secret passage, and exit by it.)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: I cannot read through the mask.Re-enter Desmarets.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: So our deposit is safe! Your departure from Prague was so abrupt, I fancied you were in a hurry to transmit certain papers to the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You see I have respected your confidence.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Hm!—At least I see you have not had time to make use of it.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: M. Desmarets, pardon my sudden flight. I had motives.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh, a lady is not bound to have any, you know, nor to tell them if she has!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: But tell me,—what did M. de Neuville think, say, of my disappearance?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh! you don't expect me to repeat a lover's incoherencies—for I find he is a very warm lover. I congratulate you on the success of that part of your mission. But the best of it is, he is under the impression, poor innocent, that you love him!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: That I love him! Ah, he is so inexperienced—and these Creoles are so passionate! And then I played my part so well! It was my part to appear to love him! Love him! (forcing a laugh) No! Ha, ha, ha! I was not there to love him! But what matter what he thinks? You know the truth!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (R. C.)I do. Shall I tell it you?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (L. C.)Me, Desmarets?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Yes, you, Marie de Fontanges! you do love this man!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh! no, no, no—you must not believe him!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: It is not from him I know it, but from you!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Me! I tell you it is not so—I do not love him!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Will you tell him so?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh, if that will satisfy you, I will write as much to him at once! (aside) I need not send the letter.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Why write, when he is here?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Here! Here, in the very den of the wolf?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: In your house, Madame!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: You have not told him what I am—with what intentions I came to Prague?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Eh! (looks at her maliciously)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh! for mercy's sake—You have not told him of my shame?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: What matter if I have or not—you do not love him, you know; but it is time to undeceive him. I will send him to you that you may tell him you do not love him. Exit Desmarets, C. and L.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: One moment will decide all. (Enter Henri de Neuville appears, C.) Oh, Henri, Henri! my love!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Your love! that name was not meant for me. I am Henri de Neuville, Madame!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: For you—for whom else but you? Do not look at me so! Speak to me—the worst, if it must be— anything rather than this silence!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Better silence than the truth.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: The truth!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Your pardon! I forgot myself. The man whose heart you have made the plaything of your summer leisure, when he wakes to the truth may suffer,—it is a compliment to your fascination,—but that he should complain—absurd! I do not come to complain, Madame! (sternly)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (clasping her hands)Henri! why are you here?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (L. C.)To revenge!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (R. C.)Has that man betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Oh! you use the wrong word; he has opened my eyes—I know all!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: All!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: The mode of your departure—it was admirably contrived;—your companion—he was well chosen, for he was my friend!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ah! De Cevennes!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I expected to find him here. (puts his hat down, L. H.) It is from him and not you I am come to ask an explanation.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (aside)Ah! it is but jealousy, after all. Oh, Henri! be more just to me, if not to yourself, than to imagine that coxcomb could hold a place in my heart.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I did not imagine he held a place in your heart, Madame, but in that which does duty for your heart—your vanity. Besides, he had prior claims. How often has he not proclaimed himself your adorer—long—long before I had the misfortune to know you.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Henri De Neuville, look at me well. It was necessary, to save you, that I should leave Prague secretly and speedily. The Marquis De Cevennes's carriage offered me the only means. I took that means for you— and you doubt me.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Marie! Is this the truth?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Look into my eyes, as I swear to you, this is the truth.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: There is conviction in your look, Marie—I do believe you! Forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No! no! It is I who must ask for forgiveness. Oh! if you knew all!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: I know only this, that we are once more together, and that we will never part more. (they embrace; suddenly she starts away from his arms)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Hush, Henri! in my joy, I forget all!— to stay here is death.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Nay—nay. Fouché is the only enemy I have to fear, and here I am secure from him.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh! no, no—what place is safe from that man?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Yes, this place is safe. (holding her in his arms and looking on her fondly) Falsehood never sat on that pure and open brow. Treason never lurked in the depth of that clear eye. Poison never seethed in the honey of these lips. (he kisses her)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: His kisses scald like molten lead. Oh! Fly! fly! Henri! Every minute it may be too late!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (at the window)I begin to think it is too late already. (crosses to R. C. behind)

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ah! (going to window) Gendarmes in the court!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Has treason followed me so close! I will not die without a struggle!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (crosses in front to R.)(aside to Desmarets) Stay. (pointing, R.) There is a passage here—(she rushes to picture—tries the spring) It will not work!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Oh! I forgot to explain to you the counter spring.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Lost! lost! Oh! no—(crosses to L.) at least stay here, Henri. The Gendarmes may retire; we do not know they come for you.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Doubtless they do. I am betrayed. I may yet discover the traitor.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (R.)You may, easily—shall I reveal his name?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (C.)You? Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (L.)No, no—for mercy's sake!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (C.)Where is he?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (R., smiling coldly and pointing to Madame De Fontanges)There!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (laughs scornfully)M. Lebon, our rapid journey has disordered your wits! This is Madame De Fontanges! a pure and stainless woman, and my love! Her honour is mine!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I am sorry for it. I tell you—

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Oh, mercy! mercy! Do not!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: There stands the woman who, when you escaped hence, followed you to Prague to win your affections and lure you back to death at Paris—your affections are hers— you are in Paris—she has obeyed her orders—(she sinks on her knees, L. C., hiding her face) as becomes the spy, the decoy of Fouché.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Liar!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (shrugs his shoulders)Look there! (points to her)

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Marie, you hear him? Tell him as I have told him—he lies! likes like a coward! How's this? No word? You hide your eyes when they should strike him dumb! Marie, speak to me, if not to him; say he lies! Oh! God! he lies! Marie, does he not lie?

div.stage: Enter Fouché, C., in Court dress.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (C.)Let me answer that!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: The Abbe Lenoir—in this dress!—but you know her, Abbé!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: First let me set you right about myself! I am Fouché, though, thanks to Madame's complaisance, I have been occasionally allowed to usurp the character of her confessor.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: She needs one no longer now; I have confessed for her!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Let her agony save her the pain of an avowal. Accept my assurance that what this gentleman has said is, oddly enough, the truth! (De Neuville sinks into a chair, R. C., and hides his head on his folded arms, which rest on the table)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (to Madame de Fontanges, who has dragged herself up to a chair and sits on it, ghastly pale)I told you the serpent could sting! (crosses to L. C.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: This shock is naturally overpowering at first, but you will get over it,—particularly with the advantages for cool reflection which you will have in Vincennes, to which safe and retired residence I have particular pleasure in consigning the brilliant and sarcastic Timon! (goes up stage) Lest you should make any attempt at escape, I may inform you that the house is guarded at every exit. And now, Desmarets, perhaps we had better leave them together a little—they may need some mutual explanation. (looking at Madame de Fontanges) Poor creature! she threatened me, Desmarets! (going off C. and L.)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah,—And she spurned me—but I bear no malice! following Fouché by C.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: (struggles up and walks falteringly to where De Neuville sits. She stands before him with her head bent down.)Henri! M. de Neuville!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Still here!—I hoped I was alone! (he turns from her, throws his head down on the table, and sobs bitterly. She approaches him and tries to take his hand—he looks up fiercely) Do not touch me! I wish I could have spared you the sight of this humiliation. It is not for myself I am so shaken, but that you—you whom I had set so high in my heart should be so fallen! A spy! worse— a decoy!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: It is true; but let me not hear it from your lips. Spare me! spare me! I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (passionately)Why cross my path? What wrong have I done to you that you should wreck my happiness thus? Why do you stay?—Is it to look on the ruin you have made? Why are you not with them for the wages of your work?—You have earned them well—too well!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No, no, no!—do not look at me so— speak so! I was not vile enough to finish what I had the vileness to begin. I loved you, Henri, at last—truly, fondly loved you—with the love before which life and death are indifferent. Only one thing I could not bear—your scorn! It was dread of this that kept me from avowing the shameful truth that sometimes made your softest words daggers. If you knew the weight of self-scorn I bore under my happiness in your love—my nights of bitter tears—my days of hidden shame—fallen as I am, you would pity me, Henri— indeed you would! (still kneeling.)

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: How am I to know this tone does not mask some new treachery?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No! my shame is revealed now—and that—that was all I ever concealed from you!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: And your flight was not to draw me to my destruction?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: No!—as I live, no! It was to try one last appeal to Fouché for release from my infamy.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: But what could she have been who could first lend herself to such ignominy?

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: A gambler, Henri!—enticed to the table by Fouché's arts—beggared there by his agents—and then, when ruin and dishonour beset me, the tempter was ever at my elbow with gold. I listened—I fell—I became his spy; once fallen to that, the man who tempted me ordered me to tempt you—and I did tempt you—wretched woman as I am —you, for whom if I had a thousand lives I would give them all!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Poor, poor Marie! My suffering dates but a few hours back, and yours has been the misery of years!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p:
(rises and advances, C.)But is the agony I feel now no atonement for my past, Henri? I feel as if it might be—my suffering has been so bitter—so bitter!
You will let me take your hand, Henri? (she takes it, he does not resist) There are tears in your eyes—you look upon me as you did in those happy days when you thought me worthy of your love! I feel that I have destroyed you. Henri—forgive me, I did not mean to use that word!—May I still call you so?

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (in a broken voice)Yes, yes!

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ah! I am forgiven! Speak!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: Yes! yes, my poor Marie! I forgive the past— such suffering and such repentance redeem all! (she falls into his arms; he presses her to his heart) And so we will meet fate together! They did not look to find us thus—thy wet cheek on my loving heart! I can face imprisonment, death, now, if it must be, without a quiver! (they embrace and remain in each other's arms)Enter Fouché and Desmarets with Soldiers, C.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (speaking at the entrance)We will try that! Madame, I regret to disturb your tête àtête, but the carriage waits to conduct this gentleman to Vincennes.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Kill me! kill me! How can I live with his blood upon my head? Henri! Henri! (the Soldiers advance) Where he goes I go! To prison with him—to death with him!

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p: (L. C.)One moment, gentlemen. Joseph Fouché, so sure as there is an eternal justice above us, so surely shall this wickedness be atoned for! Aye, smile, and tremble while you smile—for you feel that truth speaks out of him, who on his way to the grave, pauses here to give you your true titles of knave and coward!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (C.)Do your duty!

sp.speaker: Berthier.
sp.p: (speaking without)Stay without, gentlemen, the carriage for Vincennes may wait.Enter De Cevennes accompanied by Berthier in a Court dress, C.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: Ha! Berthier! Prince, my prayer?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (R. C.)Is granted.

sp.speaker: Mad. de Fon.
sp.p: He is free! Henri, you are free! free! Do you hear? I said so; I knew they could not part us now! You are safe—something here at my heart told me so—you are safe! God bless the mouth that tells me so!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: M. le Duc, my errand is to you. (beckons De Cevennes and takes paper) A glance at this paper may spare painful avowals. (hands despatch) You will wait the further directions of the Emperor on your estate of Pont Carré.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (looks at despatch then to Madame) Admirably done, Madame; worthy of myself, upon my honour!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Your Grace will not wonder, after this discovery, that I am charged to demand your portfolio: you will give up your cabinet and papers to the Duke of Rovigo!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (R. C.)Savary—poor Savary! (takes snuff) Savary —after me!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (C.)Among the papers to be given up the Emperor includes all his autograph letters and instructions.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (to Berthier)I regret extremely not to be able to oblige the Emperor; but, fearing so delicate a correspondence might fall into bad hands, I have burnt it. Exit Desmarets by secret passage.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Burnt it!—you will find it difficult to convince the Emperor of that.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: I have always found him difficult to convince. But it is nevertheless true. His autographs are burnt. (Desmarets returning with box, crosses behind Fouché, to C.)

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Not all, I think, M. le Duc—not quite all.

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: You, too, Desmarets! then I am down!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Your Highness will find His Majesty's revered autographs in this box, besides much interesting correspondence with Marshal Bernadotte and the King of Naples. (aside) I should not like Joseph to fall without my having a hand in it (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: Prince, I am a victim to calumny. I resign my portfolio and myself, until His Majesty again requires my services. Desmarets—no—I leave you to my successor ad interim. I have only to hope he will find you as trustworthy as I have done—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: (R.)Adieu!

sp.speaker: Fou.
sp.p: (R. C., looking at him fixedly)No, au revoir! Madame, permit me to compliment you on the skill of your play! M. de. Neuville, you have acquired a jewel. Treasure it, but don't forget you took it out of the mire.

sp.speaker: Neuv.
sp.p:
(L. C.)I will remember it, Duke of Otranto. Think
you how precious must be that jewel, which, for a moment soiled by contact with your hands, is yet worthy of being set here—in the heart of an honest man! (He takes her to his arms—she falls on his neck)

p.l: If from the whirl of passion, plot, and play
My storm-tossed bark seeks wedded life's calm bay,
What tamed the gambler's passion in my heart?
What 'gainst the plotter turned his own deep art?
What made weak hands strong for a giant's fall?
The master-passion, Love—“that still is lord of all.”
